Module map_.py¶

This module is responsible for defining classes to represent the map. The two types of maps are made with tiles, that are also implemented here. The file containing the map data is located inside map folder, and to declare a map a list of lists is used.

class src.map_.BackgroundTile(image, position)¶

Class representing a tile of the map. A tile is a square that is part of the map background.

Parameters:

  • image (pg.surface.Surface) – A pygame image object. It should be previously scaled to tile size.

  • position (tuple) – The position of the tile in the world.

class src.map_.Map(layout)¶

Class representing a map. It contains a grid with the tiles of the map.

Parameters:

layout (list) – An matrix representing the tile placement in the map.

property background: Group¶

A pygame group containing multiple tiles. The tiles are made based on layout and have correct positions.

property dimensions: tuple¶

The dimensions, in pixels, of the background. It’s important to notice that this isn’t the map dimensions in tiles.

property layout: list¶

The layout the map needs to follow. Overriding it will automatically update the background property.

property rect: Rect¶

A rectangle representing the map boundaries. It’s dimensions represent the dimensions of the map in pixels, not in tiles.

class src.map_.RepeatMap(layout)¶

Class representing a repeating map. It contains a grid with the tiles of the map. This class is capable of moving some map tiles to other side, creating a illusion of an infinite map

Parameters:

layout (list) – An matrix representing the tile placement in the map. Every new part of the map will be moved based on that.

expand(rect)¶

Updates the map, based in a rectangle, so it covers all the space in the rectangle with tiles. The tiles are moved from one border to another, so the number of tiles never change at all.

Parameters:

rect (pg.Rect) – The rectangle to use to move the map

Return type:

None

property rect: Rect¶

A rectangle representing the map boundaries. It’s dimensions represent the dimensions of the map in pixels, not in tiles.
